questions.question_text: A vendor connects a laptop to the projector for a presentation but notices the projector is not listed as a display in the display properties. Which of the following troubleshooting steps should be done FIRST?

A user reports that a laptop is not connecting to the corporate wireless network. A technician confirms with a smartphone that the corporate wireless network is available and can be accessed. The technician observes that the Ethernet connection to the corporate network is working. The technician disconnects the
Ethernet cable.
Which of the following should the technician do NEXT to troubleshoot this problem?

discussion.content: What did the ethernet cable have to do with anything then? was the users laptop connected via ethernet or wireless before the troubleshooting process? if it was connected via ethernet, and the ethernet was working, there should be no problem. however the users laptop wasn't, because it didn't connect. I guess that's how you tell he tried connecting through the NIC of that specific laptop, and it didn't work

comments.content: They probably mentioned it as a "by the way, physical connection works but Wireless doesn't", to make it slightly easier to think of the solution.
yeah, this seems poorly worded. The Tech verified that the laptop successfully connects to the network via a wired connection therefore the issue is with the NIC

discussion.content: So the network is available to everyone because it works, but on this specific device (the laptop), it doesn't work. It does however work via ethernet. Now I remember in class being told that there is an ethernet NIC and a wireless NIC. So if connecting via ethernet works and not wirelessly, there might be a problem with your wireless NIC. So definitely A.

Since the user can connect via ethernet and its not stated if the user can see the wireless network, then it is more than one correct option here.
It could be a login ID and password issue or user forgot to turn On wireless card.

The technician checked if the NIC is working by connecting an ethernet cable, so it must be a problem only with the wireless connection. Therefore the first thing to check is to make sure he is connected to the right SSID, not a guest network.

Selected Answer: A
I think A is the correct answer.
Think about it this way... It won't matter whether you know the correct SSID, Wifi password, or within range if the wireless NIC is not even enabled! :)
Way back in the mid '90s, it was always drilled into us to Always check the physical connection first. In this instance, the wireless card would be the physical connection.

In This Scenario, The User is Still Able to Access the Network Via the Ethernet & Not Able to Connect Via Wireless.
Thus the Tech Needed to Disconnect the Ethernet First so as to Replicate Issue.
With That Cleared, In Order to Connect to Wifi, First Step is to Turn on the Wifi (Wireless) That is : laptop wireless card

comments.content: Yes totally agree with that answer. Range is not an issue here.

discussion.content: Yet another example of why we need someone who is an IT Tech verified expert to comment in this discussion.

I don't understand again! If it's not connecting, then I would assume that the wifi card is turned on and they were attempting to connect. So I would check that it is within a good range and if the settings are configured correctly.

comments.content: I agree, my first answer would be to check if it's in range
Disagree if the smart phone picked up the signal itâ€™s not that. Assuming he is standing near the pc when looking. NIC is correct
I doubt if this has anything to do with range though. The technician would have used the phone to check for the availability of the wireless network while working to resolve the issue with the PC.

choices.B: Confirm that the laptop is in range for the access point.
choices.C: Confirm that the correct wireless network is selected.
choices.A: Confirm that the laptop wireless card is turned on.
choices.D: Confirm the user's network login ID and password.

discussion.content: Yes. I hate when I physically find a cable but can't see it ... This exam is ridiculous.

questions.question_text:
A technician discovered a spare cable at a user's desk. The ends of the cable terminate in a plastic connector with four pins, only two of which contain conductors.
Which of the following connector types did the technician find?

discussion.content: is BD correct?cus I am thinking DE,can they use guest to login and use cloud to work?
Does anyone else know if the answer is right or wrong? Please explain.
"Install OS and applications" FALSE. You can't install an OS and all apps right before the office opens. I'm going with AB

comments.content: Yes you can, this method is called imaging. Good luck setting up system policies without an Operating System.

choices.B: Set up local accounts per station.
choices.E: Synchronize user files to the cloud.
choices.C: Set up mailbox quotas per account.

questions.question_text:
A technician is deploying PCs in a new office that has both wired and wireless connectivity. The deployment must be completed quickly, since the office is scheduled to open soon. Which of the following must the technician perform to ensure the devices are ready for use when the newly hired employees arrive?
(Choose two.)

discussion.content: A file server is a computer responsible for the storage and management of data files so that other computers on the same network (LAN) can access the files. It enables users to share information over a network without having to physically transfer files.

questions.question_text: Which of the following servers provides access to user data over a LAN?
